title: Bures Walks

images.title: The River Stour from the bridge at Bures by Adrian S Pye, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The River Stour from the bridge at Bures

images.title: David Sanderson / River Stour North of Wormingford
images.caption: River Stour North of Wormingford

images.title: Bob Jones / River Stour at Bures
images.caption: River Stour at Bures. A footpath leads alongside the river, from Colchester Road to the Primary School. This view upstream is towards the centre of the village. The river marks the boundary between Essex (from where the photo was taken) and Suffolk, on the opposite bank.

images.title: Bob Jones / Wiston Hall
images.caption: Wiston Hall. Adjacent to the church, this red-brick building assumes the as-pronounced version of the hamlet of Wissington.

images.title: Bob Jones / River Stour at Nayland
images.caption: River Stour at Nayland. The 42-mile long River Stour flows from near West Wickham in Cambridgeshire to Harwich. From much of the route it follows the Essex/Suffolk border. Here at Nayland, as elsewhere in the Stour valley, it is prone to flooding. But not on this fine June day.

images.title: Gated Field by Keith Evans, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gated Field on the St Edmund Way

images.title: John Lemay / "Over the hill"
images.caption: "Over the hill". Part of the St Edmunds Way, east of Bures in Suffolk

description: This pretty village is located in a lovely spot on the River Stour on the Suffolk/Essex county border. There's some lovely river trails and the wonderful Dedham Vale AONB just to the east. This circular walk from the village uses sections of the Stour Valley Path and the St Edmund Way to explore the area to the east of the settlement. The walk starts in the village centre where you can pick up the Stour Valley Path. Follow the waymarked trail south east and it will take you past Bures Mill and Wormingford Mere to the neighbouring village of Wormingford. The route continues past Garnons Chase, Bottengoms and Little Horkesley where you turn north to Wiston Mill and Weir. From here it is a short walk into Nayland where you could stop for a rest and refreshment at what is roughly the half way point on the walk. From Nayland you head west to pick up the St Edmund Way. This long distance footpath will take you west through the countryside back to Bures. This section of the walk passes Wissington Grange and the Arger Fen bird reserve.
